articles.title: DON MACHHOLZ DISCOVERS HIS 3RD COMET !
articles.summary: The article announces Don Machholz's discovery of his third comet, celebrating his achievement. It also details a comprehensive schedule of upcoming astronomical events and club activities from June to July, including field expeditions to various state parks, star parties, introductory astronomy classes, and a Halley's Comet wrap-up night featuring astrophotography and observing experiences. An annual club picnic is also planned.

articles.title: BY: JOHN GLEASON
articles.summary: The article announces the annual SJAA Glacier Point Star Party in Yosemite for July 4th and 5th, with group camping reservations available. It also reports on the recent discovery of Comet Machholz 1986e, Don Machholz's third comet, and the discontinuation of C.T. English School as a local observing site. Additionally, it details the upcoming Astronomical Society of the Pacific (ASP) Annual Meeting in Boulder, Colorado, and solicits member reports on Comet Halley observations.

articles.title: Trudy Bell
articles.summary: Trudy Bell was a prominent figure in amateur astronomy during her high school and college years, serving as a bulletin writer, expedition leader, and club president. Her career transitioned from Lick Observatory technician and NASA mission controller to a prolific science writer, with over 150 articles and a science fiction novelette. The document also announces her upcoming talk, "SCHMALIZ, SEX & SCIENCE," at the Chabot Observatory on June 7, 1986.

articles.title: MISSING HALLEY ASTROPHOTOS
articles.summary: Jack Zeiders is reporting 5 missing Halley's Comet astrophotography slides that he displayed at an indoor star party on April 19th at the Los Gatos Red Cross. He suspects they may have been accidentally mixed with other slides in a shared tray. Zeiders requests anyone who showed slides that evening to check for his and contact him.

articles.title: MEMBERSHIP RENEWAL TIME AGAIN
articles.summary: The San Jose Astronomical Association (SJAA) is reminding members that it's time to renew their memberships. Members who subscribe to Sky & Telescope should send their S&T renewal notice, the SJAA membership application, and $21 to Jack Peterson, while those subscribing only to the Ephemeris should send the application and $8. Prompt renewal is crucial to ensure uninterrupted delivery of both Sky & Telescope and the Ephemeris, with the July '86 Ephemeris being the last for non-renewers.

articles.title: COMET COMMENTS BY DON MACHHOLZ
articles.summary: Don Machholz provides updates on several comets, noting Comet Halley's fading and the discovery of Comet Singer-Brewster. He details the periodic Comet Hartley 2 (1986c), including its recently calculated 6.2-year orbit, past visibility challenges due to its position relative to the sun, and future potential observation windows in 1997 and 2003.

articles.title: WHAT GOES AROUND COMES AROUNDâ€”HALLEY'S
articles.summary: Halley's Comet is currently visible in the western evening sky until mid-July before reappearing in the morning at magnitude 13. Observations from both hemispheres describe a large comet, at times with a fan-shaped or strongly-defined tail. Preliminary reports from space probes indicate an oblong, very dark nucleus twice the predicted size with material jets, suggesting a more violent environment than expected.

articles.title: Periodic Comet Halley (1982i)
articles.summary: This article provides an observing guide for Comet Halley (1982i) for the period from May 25 to July 4. It details moon phases and their impact on observing windows, along with an ephemeris table including the comet's coordinates, elongation, estimated magnitude, and setting times. The document also provides distances from the comet to the Sun and Earth, and instructions for adjusting observation times based on observer longitude.

articles.title: THE CELESTIAL TOURIST SPEAKS
articles.summary: The article presents two distinct pieces. The first, "THE CELESTIAL TOURIST SPEAKS," reviews essential astronomical books, charts, and guides, categorizing their uses from basic orientation to advanced deep-sky work, and recommends specific titles for various observer levels. The second, "BLACKER THAN THE INSIDE OF A COW," is a personal narrative detailing a transformative 1986 observing trip to New Zealand, highlighting the unparalleled clarity and beauty of the southern skies, including views of Halley's Comet and the Magellanic Clouds.

articles.title: WHY NEW ZEALAND?
articles.summary: The article explains why New Zealand was an ideal location for observing Halley's Comet, citing its extreme southern latitude which placed the comet at the zenith and made it visible all night, as well as a micro-climate providing surprisingly clear, dark skies despite the fall season. It highlights the country's lack of industrial light pollution, leading to exceptionally dark conditions comparable to Fremont Peak, enabling observations of objects like the Magellanic Clouds and Omega Centauri at sites such as the West Melton Observatory.

articles.title: THE MACKENZIE BASIN AND THE HALLEY WATCH SITE
articles.summary: The article recounts a 3-day trip to New Zealand's Mackenzie Basin for observing Halley's Comet. Participants visited the Mount John Observatory, where they saw an 8x10 glass plate of Halley, and later struggled with logistical issues and a strong smell at a public 'Halley Watch Site'. Ultimately, the group found a superior, dark observing location behind their hotel, where they shared their astronomical equipment and observations with delighted locals.

articles.title: SOUTHERN CELESTIAL WONDERS
articles.summary: This article details astronomical observations of Southern Celestial Wonders, recounting a initially clouded-out first night followed by a phenomenal second night at the Omarawa site. Observers marveled at the Large and Small Magellanic Clouds, with particular attention to the Tarantula Nebula and the impressive globular cluster 47 Tucanae, which was highly praised and compared to other notable clusters. The document also includes a special notice about membership rate changes.

articles.title: ORION AND THE SOUTHERN MILKY WAY
articles.summary: The article vividly describes an awe-inspiring observing session of the Southern Milky Way, detailing the vast array of celestial objects visible from a location where the winter Milky Way was prominently displayed. The author recounts mesmerizing views of the Coalsack, the Southern Cross, multiple star systems like Alpha Crucis and Alpha Centauri, the magnificent Omega Centauri globular cluster, and the distinct radio galaxy Centaurus A (NGC 5128). The observations highlight unique visual features, such as the sharpness of stars in Omega Centauri and the detailed dark band within Centaurus A, leaving a lasting impression on the observer.

articles.title: HALLEY'S COMET OVER OMARAMA, APRIL 8, 9, 10
articles.summary: This article details observations of Halley's Comet over Omarama, New Zealand, from April 8-10, noting its unusual appearance with a short, fan-shaped tail compared to earlier sightings. Observers debated whether the diminished tail was due to its proximity to the Milky Way, Earth/comet positional geometry where they were looking into the comet's 'nose,' or a detached tail, with different observatories offering conflicting theories. Despite the comet's atypical display, the observers expressed no disappointment, cherishing its memorable position in the Southern Milky Way.

articles.title: TWIZEL'S REVENGE STRIKES THE HALLEY'S COMET SKY WATCH!
articles.summary: A sky watch for Halley's Comet at Omarama on April 10th was marred by a sudden, severe illness striking several participants, including the author, who suffered chills and nausea. The group suspected the illness was caused by contaminated food, possibly pickled eel or the 'catch-of-the-day,' turning what should have been an astrophotography session into a night they'd rather forget.

articles.title: SOLITAIRE LODGE, LAKE TARAWERA, ROTORUA
articles.summary: After a period of illness and poor observing conditions, the author and a few tour members were invited to Solitaire Lodge in Rotorua, New Zealand, for a Halley's Comet Skywatch fest. They met amateur astronomer Graham Loftus, who had constructed a 22-inch reflector telescope, enabling them to capture numerous astrophotographs of the comet. The highlight was using the large telescope for breathtaking observations of deep-sky objects, including the Tarantula Nebula, 47 Tucanae, and Omega Centauri, under a pristine sky.

articles.title: NASA'S LAUNCHER PROBLEMS CONTINUE
articles.summary: Following the Challenger disaster, the U.S. space program has faced further setbacks with two failed expendable booster launches. A Titan 34D exploded due to a solid booster failure, destroying a Big Bird satellite, while a Delta booster shut down due to low battery voltage, resulting in the loss of a GOES weather satellite. These failures have prompted significant delays, with future Atlas and other scheduled launches postponed by several months for investigation.

articles.title: SHUTTLE INVESTIGATION REPORT IS DUE JUNE 6TH
articles.summary: The investigation into the loss of the Challenger shuttle has definitively linked the accident to a leaky seal in the right-hand solid rocket booster. The panel's report, due June 6th, will recommend a redesign of the joint and changes to NASA's shuttle checkout and operational procedures. The projected return to flight timeline ranges from July 1987 if only the booster requires major redesign, to 1988 or later if broader system changes are recommended.

articles.title: CHALLENGER REPLACEMENT RECOMMENDATIONS
articles.summary: Following the Challenger disaster, NASA, the Air Force, and the White House Senior Interagency Group for Space have recommended building a replacement orbiter and more expendable boosters. Key unresolved issues include funding for the new orbiter and the potential relocation of all commercial satellites from the shuttle program. Proposed funding solutions range from additional appropriations, cuts to other NASA budgets, or private funding with lease-back arrangements.

articles.title: GIOTTO IMAGES THE NUCLEUS OF HALLEY'S COMET
articles.summary: The Giotto spacecraft successfully imaged the nucleus of Halley's Comet from 18,000 km, revealing a 14 km long, potato-shaped nucleus with active dust and gas jets on its sunlit side and an extremely dark unlit side. The European Space Agency plans to retarget Giotto for an Earth flyby in 1990 for potential future comet missions, while the Soviet Union is considering a similar retargeting of its Vega 2 spacecraft towards asteroid Adonis in 1987.

articles.title: SOVIET UNION ORBITS NEW SPACE STATION
articles.summary: The Soviet Union launched its new modular space station, Mir, on February 19th, followed by its first two-man crew on March 13th for long-duration missions. The station is designed for expansion with up to six additional modules. The Mir/Soyuz also rendezvoused with the older Salyut 7, facilitating a transfer of cosmonauts, potentially to retrieve a French cometary dust collector or inspect the Cosmos 1686 module.

articles.title: LATE COMET MACHHOLZ POSITION UPDATE
articles.summary: This article provides an updated ephemeris for Comet Machholz (1986e) for early June, detailing its Right Ascension, Declination, and estimated visual magnitudes. It serves as a guide for observers interested in locating the comet. An old Sky and Telescope hotline number is also mentioned for additional information.

articles.title: GENERAL MEETINGS
articles.summary: The SJAA holds monthly General Meetings and "Indoor Star Parties" at the Los Gatos Red Cross building, offering a friendly atmosphere for members to share various astronomical interests. Meetings begin at 8 PM on the 4th Saturday of each month, with directions and parking information provided for the Los Gatos, California location.

articles.title: HENRY COE STATE PARK
articles.summary: This document provides detailed driving directions to Henry Coe State Park, starting from Hwy 101 South near Morgan Hill, and specifies access details for a particular observing site. It includes a club combination for a locked gate (4565) and advises on parking and scouting for an observing site if arriving after dark, where the SJAA typically sets up equipment.

articles.title: FREMONT PEAK STATE PARK
articles.summary: Fremont Peak State Park, situated at 3000 ft, is a popular astronomical observing site frequently used by the San Jose Astronomical Association (SJAA). The SJAA hosts regular gatherings at Coulter Camp during clear new moon weekends, often attracting 30-40 telescopes. The document also provides detailed directions to the park, information about the SJAA's monthly publication 'EPHEMERIS', and a list of current club officers and board members.

articles.title: SAN JOSE ASTRONOMICAL ASSOCIATION MEMBERSHIP APPLICATION
articles.summary: This document is a membership application form for the San Jose Astronomical Association (SJAA). It outlines different membership tiers, including Membership Only, Membership/S&T, and Junior (Under 18), along with their respective costs. The form requests applicant contact information and provides instructions for submission to the association's treasurer.

articles.title: Questionnaire (optional)
articles.summary: This document presents an optional questionnaire designed to gather information on individuals' astronomical interests, telescope ownership, and areas where they might offer assistance. It also includes contact and postage information for the "SJAA EPHEMERIS," a non-profit organization located in San Jose, CA, labeled as dated news material.
